entry.title: Peer review and request for comments
entry.summary: Laurent Romary and myself have authored an RFC. That means a Request For Comments. I now understand why.

div.p: Earlier this year Laurent Romary and myself authored an Internet Draft, which the first step to an Request For Comments (RFC). Now this text has been trough the review process and we have made all the revisions required. Finally it has now been approved by the IESG's review process. I now understand the RFC concept.

Internet was created by people connected to the DARPA net with the first serious experimental work starting around 1968. The people who did it were affiliated to various US universities and a few companies capable mean, you send your idea on how Internet can be made better to your fellow researches in ARPA net.

It seems that these people communicated their findings by storing and circulating as odd text files on the very infrastructures that were the subjects for their research. And now more than forty years later there still is this mix of individuals from academic and corporate research environments from all over the world. Friendly geeks who want that the Internet should be good place. So, when you submit a draft you do get comments, a lot of them but all were constructive and friendly.
